ygData.messageBody:
This arguement still doesn't make sense to me in a realm where some of the
opponents are taller than houses.

I don't care how big your axe is, you aren't going to be able to do the
damage that a caster can to some creatures, like a hill giant.

You argument just doesn't make sense when you apply it to the setting in EQ.
Sure I can hack someone's head off in a single swipe and a mage could blast
them to ashes. However, that same sword swipe will be nothing more than an
annoyance to a giant, where that same fireball from the mage will do
devastating damage.

Making the warrior a huge damage dealing machine was never the intent of
Verant and isn't in the spirit of EQ's balanced group oriented world.
Verant needs to allow us to have an advantage of the other melee/caster
hybrids is the main point of our discussion I think.

>I think the difference between melee combatants and casters magic should be
>thus: Melee fighters should be able to do just as much damage, if not
more,
>whereas a caster may strike from a distance, and strike multiple targets
>with area effect spells.
>
>I am the president of a national group that fights with live steel weapons.
>I've been fighting with long swords, 2-handed swords, axes and maces for 10
>years, and I am very comfortable with just how devastating these weapons
can
>be. No matter if you are struck by lightning or are cut in 2 by a large
>axe, you are just as dead!
>
>So perhaps the direction we need to seek, and the difference between these
2
>types of characters. melee and caster, is not how much damage they do, but
>how. A caster should be able to reach far away, and strike multiple
>targets, while the great warrior should only be able to strike at one
target
>at a time, but be able to mow them down like wheat.
